_Wow!_ ["Kiducation"]

Not Hobo.

There's an overpriced pizza place near me that uses Hobo exclusively for their identity, menu, etc. Surprisingly, it looks okay. I think the reason Hobo usually looks bad is because it's usually used by people who want to use all the fonts they have at the same time, and _nothing_ goes _with_ Hobo.

Some of the Indian tribes here in California have been running ads illustrating how their casinos are benefiting their people and society in general.  
I notice that on many of the official buildings shown in these ads, the signage is lettered in Hobo.

Just sayin' what I'm seein'.

<cite>Not Hobo.</cite>

Nick's right. "Kiducation" is set in Berlin Sans (possibly squooshed). No Hobo in sight there.

_merkri, this is just for you! :-)_

Ahh...now I remember.

Thanks for retraumatizing me with things I had obviously pushed to the dark recesses of my memory.

:)

For some reason, Hobo still doesn't rub me the same way as Comic Sans or Papyrus, but I see your point.

I think this would only be a big challenge if you do a lot of work for spas and Thai restaurants (Papyrus), an elementary school (Comic Sans), and for Hobo... I guess maybe Korean nail salons in strip malls? I don't know if Hobo is really overly used anymore, although I guess it was 10, 20 years ago. But I don't think I've ever been forced into using those typefaces, and I would imagine a good portion of designers have never used them either. Just because they're visible in the American (and probably global) landscape doesn't mean graphic designers are to blame -- I think it's usually churn and burn signmakers who are so cheap they only have the fonts pre-installed on Windows at their disposal.

That said, this pledge can't hurt anything. Although maybe a more interesting challenge (possibly a Typophile challenge?) would be to use these three typefaces in an appealing way.

_FeeltheKern: and burn signmakers_ I like that.

It's not that signmakers are necessarily too cheap. They just don't have the software/fonts budget the Ivory Tower graphic designers have.

I've always thought it was humorous in a gruesome sort of way that most folks will pay out the nose when they go to a graphic designer, but quibble over every nickle when it comes to getting their signs made.

As for the fonts, you should see the mess a CNC router table makes of Papyrus, one of my boss's favorite fonts. And yes, he is too cheap.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~

[_...from the Fontry_](http://web.archive.org/web/20100923100346/http:/www.thefontry.com/)

_...Papyrus, one of my boss’s favorite fonts._

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100923100346im_/http:/typophile.com/files/apocalypse-brando2_6509.jpg)

Horror is the client with 10 revisions for a $65 project...ARGH!!!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~

[_...from the Fontry_](http://web.archive.org/web/20100923100346/http:/www.thefontry.com/)

I think the reason Papyrus is used so much these days is that it is a font that says "non-Western" but which doesn't seem to invoke any bad ethnic stereotypes.

So it's heavily used because it is an obvious choice that fills a real pressing need in today's world.

And, thus, of course it's used for purposes that have nothing to do with Ancient Egypt, but instead, say, India or the Far East - one place I see it every day is in advertisements for "Trade Winds for Success", a local program of pre-apprenticeship training offered to persons of Native American descent.

My complaint isn't necessarily that Papyrus is overused. For signs, it is too light and too node heavy. The software for the CNC machine faints when it is mentioned, and plotters chew it up on the vinyl.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~

[_...from the Fontry_](http://web.archive.org/web/20100923100346/http:/www.thefontry.com/)

And, in 2010, I resolve to use punctuation.
